Another reason why random select game modes (like ARAM) should just use a fully unlocked champion pool.

Maybe because the issue with old URF is that 90% of the good champions were champions who didn't use CDR/MANA items since those items still have the same stats, cost the same amount of gold, but the items are terrible in URF just due to the stats on them.

It sucks because I look at Taric and know that I all but require an IBG to function.  Then I look at the item and read "65 armour, 2700 gold."

People complain about the stale meta but the meta is just CD dependent champions that use items that weren't nerfed because they are mostly mana/CDR.  If that actually got changed URF might not be the exact same team every game.

The only items with mana that are actually still good pick ups are ROA and Seraphs Embrace because the stats on them + Seraphs active overshadow the uselessness of mana on the items.  Heck just leave those two items as they are and change all the other mana/cdr/mana regen items and there will still be options for Ryze and Kassadin.

It's not just that.  There are champions that are a complete terror to fight.

Like Wukong, for example.  He's not ridiculous in URF because his mana management issues are gone.  He's ridiculous because he's in basically permanent stealth while leaving clones everywhere and a lot of champs can't even target him with their abilities while he kills them.

Read again, it isn't about mana management, it is about champions that synergize with items like IBG that do poorly because no matter what they buy they are getting shafted.  

General states definitely have an impact too, but look at Taric.  He has all the tools to do amazingly in URF.  Despite that he is meh because he either has to build items he dislikes or build items that are horrendously inefficient because they are mostly mana/CDR.  You basically can't buy IBG for the passive in URF without getting screwed over one way or another.

Pretending that items have no impact is just silly.  Look at lethality right after the buff.  Despite crit not having been hit at all crit ADC's all but vanished off the face of the earth for a patch.  Is it really so surprising that URF has a stale meta when half the items that half the champion pool uses are only half as useful as normal?

Take a look at defensive items:
{{item:3001}} {{item:3102}} {{item:3060}} {{item:3174}} {{item:3742}} {{item:3814}} {{item:1401}} {{item:3401}} {{item:2303}}{{item:3110}}  {{item:2302}} {{item:3022}} {{item:3026}} {{item:3030}} {{item:3152}} {{item:3025}} {{item:3109}} {{item:3151}} {{item:3190}} {{item:3156}} {{item:3139}} {{item:3111}} {{item:3222}} {{item:3047}} {{item:3056}} {{item:3143}} {{item:3107}} {{item:3800}} {{item:3027}} {{item:2045}} {{item:3116}} {{item:3040}} {{item:3065}} {{item:3068}} {{item:3053}} {{item:3069}} {{item:3071}} {{item:3075}} {{item:3748}} {{item:3078}} {{item:3083}} {{item:3091}} {{item:3050}} {{item:3157}} {{item:3512}} 

These are every completed item that provide defensive stats (Not passives, hence why Last whisper and the like aren't included.)

Now lets look at how many of these don't lose the stats they are balanced around and priced for in URF:
{{item:3102}} {{item:3742}} {{item:3814}} {{item:1401}} {{item:3022}} {{item:3026}} {{item:3109}} {{item:3151}} {{item:3190}} {{item:3139}} {{item:3111}} {{item:3047}} {{item:3143}} {{item:3116}} {{item:3053}} {{item:3068}} {{item:3075}} {{item:3748}} {{item:3083}} {{item:3091 {{item:3512}} {{item:3091}} 

Less than half as many items, and how many of those are true defensive options for tanks?  I know Taric isn't interested in half of those items.  He isn't going to be buying and edge of night or a QSS.  Rylais is wasted and he doesn't actually use the AS from Wits End due to his passive.

Lets compare that to AD/AS damage items:
{{item:3006}} {{item:3153}} {{item:3812}} {{item:3147}} {{item:3814}} {{item:1416}} {{item:1400}} {{item:3508}} {{item:3022}} {{item:3124}} {{item:3146}} {{item:3031}} {{item:3036}} {{item:3004}} {{item:3156}} {{item:3139}} {{item:3033}} {{item:3115}} {{item:3046}} {{item:3094}} {{item:3074}} {{item:3085}} {{item:3087}} {{item:3053}} {{item:3071}} {{item:3072}} {{item:3748}} {{item:3078}} {{item:3091}} {{item:3142}} 

These are any completed items that grant AD or AS.  Admittedly fewer items than the defense options, but you have to keep in mind defense options are vs both AD and AP which only 2-3 of these items are ok buys on most AP champs outside of those like Kayle who just want to abuse AS whatever the form.

After we cut down the list we are left with:
{{item:3006}} {{item:3153}} {{item:3147}} {{item:3814}} {{item:1416}} {{item:3022}} {{item:3146}} {{item:3031}} {{item:3036}} {{item:3139}} {{item:3046}} {{item:3094}} {{item:3074}} {{item:3085}} {{item:3087}} {{item:3053}} {{item:3072}} {{item:3748}} {{item:3091}} 

In comparison to defensive items we lost far fewer.

Can you really say that a stagnation of a gamemode's meta has nothing to do with the fact that roughly half of all items in the game lose out on stats that they are balanced around?  That it is only coincidence that many of the strongest URF champions normally build items that didn't get hit by this nerf?  That many strong champions that did get their normal itemization hit have other options they can turn to?

Sure many of those items make a comeback due to strong passives/actives like Death's Dance which has a passive that effectively scales with CDR since it lets abilities heal you or Hextech Protobelt which has a strong active.

I played Hexakill when it was on SR, it really REALLY didn't work out that way. Unless the sixth person picked another support there wasn't enough gold on the map to support them. It works on TT better because more people are starved of farm gold and so most get it from kill gold and since there are so many fights the game progresses at a good pace without leaving anyone too far behind.

And thats where I disagree with you. The game modes dont HAVE to be about brawling - we see that through Doombots or Nexus Siege, and even with OFA to a point since they took it from Howling Abyss to Summoners Rift. Nemesis Draft was even good. The ones about the brawl were URF and Ascention. 

Hex has potential to be a strategy game instead of a brawl. I often did see it work out that way - some teams would go for scaling with the double support, others would go for the earlygame with the double jungle. I didnt see dual mid too often, but I remember facing it once and trying it rightafter. And personally, I think game progression SHOULD include scaling and snowballing. I hate how on TT, it seems that everybody ends up with full build unless you get stomped. You can do really well in the earlygame with an earlygame comp, but if the enemy has some decent waveclear in each lane and hold their inhib turrets youre free to pick the AP Ezreal and wreak at 20 minutes.
Hexakill is designed for brawling. It's the brawling game mode. There's not enough difference between normal SR and Hexakill on SR for Riot to justify putting it up again.

And again - this is where we disagree. Hexkill on SR, which was the first map it was released with, was NOT designed for brawling. It was designed similar to SR. Putting Hex on TT made it about brawling.
